Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Postdischarge Video-Based Virtual Visits vs. In-Person Follow-Up

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were those undergoing minimally invasive appendectomy or cholecystectomy. This randomised, active, controlled noninferiority trial was conducted in an urban setting, involving patients from a small community hospital and a large tertiary care hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive either video-based virtual visits or in-person visits.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the outcomes of 30-day hospital encounters among patients receiving virtual follow-up compared to in-person follow-up.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the percentage of patients with a 30-day hospital encounter, defined as an emergency department visit, observation, or inpatient admission.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 432 patients were randomised, with 289 in the virtual group and 143 in the in-person group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The hospital encounter rate was noninferior for virtual visits (12.8% vs. 13.3% for in-person, Δ 0.5% with 1-sided 95% CI, −∞ to 5.2%).
